qSOFA: quick Sequential (Sepsis-related) Organ Failure Assessment
questions.solution:
Bilateral pupillary reflex is not a component of the quick Sequential (Sepsis-related) Organ Failure Assessment (qSOFA) score.

qSOFA is a bedside assessment score. It is used to identify patients who are at risk of dying from sepsis.

It uses three criteria, assigning one point each for

  • Low blood pressure (SBP ≤100 mmHg)
  • High respiratory rate (≥22 breaths/min)
  • Altered mental status

The score ranges from 0 to 3 points. A qSOFA score of ≥2 points indicates organ dysfunction.

questions.text: An 11-month-old baby boy has an empty scrotum on the right side with normal left testis. But a mass was palpable on the right inguinal canal. Ultrasonography revealed the right testicle under the subcutaneous fat near the right inguinal canal with a normal left testis. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette is suggestive of cryptorchidism and the next best step is to perform an orchidopexy.

Orchidopexy is the treatment of choice for incompletely palpable unilateral undescended testis. Orchidopexy is usually performed before the boy reaches 12 months of age to avoid the following complications remembered by the mnemonic TESTIS:

T- Torsion
E- Epididymorchitis
S- Sterility
T- Trauma (Increased risk)
I- Increased risk of inguinal hernia (Most commonly occurring complication)
S- Seminoma (Increased risk)

About 4% of boys are born with one or both testes incompletely descended. About two-thirds of these reach the scrotum during the first 3 months of life, but full descent after that is uncommon.

Cryptorchidism is the failure of the descent of the intra-abdominal testes into the scrotal sac.  It is the most common congenital abnormality of the genitourinary tract. The testes can arrest anywhere during descent, and the most common site is the inguinal region.

Phases of testicular descent:

  • Transabdominal phase: Testes come to lie in the lower abdomen or pelvis, and this descent is regulated by Mullerian-inhibiting substances.
  • Inguinoscrotal phase: Testes descend along the inguinal canal and reach the scrotal sac, and this phase of the descent is regulated by androgen-induced calcitonin gene-related peptide from the genitofemoral nerve.

The exact pathogenesis remains unknown; however, deficiency in gonadotropins and Mullerian-inhibiting substance (MIS) and increased expression of estradiol in the placenta are thought to play a role. 

Cryptorchidism is histopathologically characterized by the following: 

  1. Testicular atrophy: thickening of the basement membrane, arrested germ cell development, marked hyalinization
  2. Tubules showing Sertoli cells but no spermatogenesis
  3. Increase in the interstitial Leydig cells 
Other options:

Option A: Cryptorchidism is associated with testicular atrophy and dysfunction, which result in sterility. Cryptorchid testes carry a 3–5-fold higher risk for testicular cancer (usually seminoma). Thus, observation is never the policy.
 
Option B: When the testis is not palpable, ultrasound may be helpful in identifying the intracanalicular testis, while laparoscopy may be needed to differentiate between the abdominal testis and a truly absent testis. Since here testis is made out in the inguinal region, laparoscopy is not the next best line of management.
 
Option D: Orchidectomy should be considered if the incompletely descended testis is atrophic, particularly in the postpubertal boy if the other testis is normal.

questions.text: A newborn is found to have a congenital urethral abnormality as shown in the image. It results in difficulty directing the urine stream. Which of the following statements regarding this condition is true?

choices.text: Dorsal chordee is a common association
Dorsal aspect of the prepuce is poorly developed
Circumcision should not be performed before corrective surgery

questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario and the image showing a urethral meatus that opens on the underside of the penis suggest hypospadias. Circumcision should not be done in hypospadias as the foreskin will be used for surgical reconstruction.

Hypospadias is the most common congenital abnormality of the urethra. It occurs due to the incomplete fusion of the urethral folds.

Hypospadias is characterized by: 

  • A ventrally placed urethral meatus (underside of penis or perineum)
  • Poor development of the ventral aspect of the prepuce (resulting in hooded foreskin)
  • Ventral chordee (bending of the penis)

Hypospadias can be classified into the following types based on the meatal location:

  • Anterior (distal)
    • Glanular (most common)
    • Coronal
  • Middle
    • Middle penile shaft
    • Distal penile shaft
  • Posterior (proximal)
    • Proximal penile shaft
    • Penoscrotal
    • Scrotal
    • Perineal

The image given below shows classification of hypospadiasis.

Surgery for correction of hypospadias are routinely performed when the patient is between 6 and 18 months of age. The infant has good tolerance to surgery by the age of 6 months. The child is well aware of his genitalia and will be toilet trained by the age of 18 months.

Surgery in hypospadias is done to correct problems with the urinary stream and for cosmetic reasons. Surgery depends on the site of the hypospadias. 

The main principles of surgery in hypospadias include:

  • Orthoplasty - Chordee correction
  • Urethroplasty - To reposition the urethral opening and tubularize urethra
  • Glanuloplasty - Reconstruction of glans
  • Skin cover and scrotoplasty

Complications of hypospadias surgery include:

  • Urethrocutaneous fistula (most common)
  • Recurrence of chordee
  • Urethral stricture
  • Meatal stenosis
  • Infection

Tubularized incised plate (TIP) urethroplasty is the most commonly done procedure. It is done for distal hypospadias.

questions.text:
Match the following surgical procedures with the corresponding conditions for which they are performed:
Procedure Condition

1. Ramstedt's procedure

A. Peyronie's disease

2. Nesbitt procedure

 B. Biliary atresia

3. Heller's operation

 C. Infantile-hypertrophic pyloric stenosis

4. Kasai procedure

 D. Achalasia cardia
questions.solution:
The correctly matched option is 1-C, 2-A, 3-D, 4-B.

  1. Ramstedt's procedure - Infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis
  2. Nesbitt procedure - Peyronie's disease
  3. Heller's operation - Achalasia cardia
  4. Kasai procedure - Biliary atresia

Ramstedt’s pyloromyotomy is performed by a laparoscopic or open supraumbilical incision for the treatment of infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis

Nesbitt procedure is the most commonly used procedure for treating Peyronie's disease. It corrects the deformity by plicating the convex side of the deformity, thereby straightening the penis.

Heller's Myotomy is done for achalasia cardia. It involves cutting the muscles of the lower esophagus and cardia of the stomach. It is often combined with a partial anterior fundoplication (Heller-Dor procedure) to avoid the complication of gastroesophageal reflux disease.

Kasai procedure (Roux-en-Y hepatoportoenterostomy) is done for all types of extrahepatic biliary atresia. In this procedure, radical excision of all bile duct tissues up to the liver capsule is performed. A Roux-en-Y loop of jejunum is anastomosed to the exposed area of the liver capsule above the bifurcation of the portal vein creating a portoenterostomy.

questions.text: In a patient with abdominal pain and sterile pyuria, what is the finding shown in the image given?
questions.solution:
In a patient with abdominal pain with sterile pyuria, the given image finding points towards a diagnosis of a putty kidney.

The putty kidney is a characteristic finding of genitourinary tuberculosis (TB), specifically renal TB. The given image shows a homogenous and ground glass-like calcification of the kidney appearing like putty.

It is caused by the dissemination of the organism through the bloodstream and is thus is always a secondary TB. There is either reinfection or reactivation of old TB.

Genitourinary TB is a cause of sterile pyuria. Diagnosis is confirmed with a tuberculin test, or at least 3 consecutive early-morning specimens of urine are examined for acid-fast bacilli. They are stained with a Ziehl–Neelsen stain and subsequently cultured.

CT is the most sensitive modality and is the preferred means of visualizing renal calcifications. CT urography is done to assess the various stages of renal TB and its manifestations which are as follows:

  • Early: Papillary necrosis
  • Progressive:
    • Multifocal strictures
    • Generalized or focal hydronephrosis
    • Mural thickening and enhancement
    • Poorly enhancing renal parenchyma
  • End-stage:
    • Progressive hydronephrosis
    • Amorphous dystrophic calcification that involves the entire kidney - putty kidney

Treatment involves short-course therapy with antitubercular drugs like pyrazinamide, isoniazid, and rifampicin. Partial nephrectomy, nephrectomy, or reconstructive surgery is often done.

Other options: Nephrocalcinosis is the deposition of calcium in the kidney parenchyma or tubules which is seen in hypercalcemia conditions like hyperparathyroidism. (option B)

Staghorn calculus is found in urinary infection with Proteus, Pseudomonas and Staphylococcus usually, and is not a cause for sterile pyuria. (Option C)

Psoas calcification is a muscle calcification and might be seen developing after acute renal failure and rhabdomyolysis. (Option D)

questions.text: A 55-year-old chronic smoker presents with painless progressive 5-cm firm, movable mass over the past 2 years as shown below. There is the displacement of tonsillar pillars and the swelling is variable in consistency. Post-surgery biopsy revealed the epithelial elements to be resembling ductal cells and myoepithelial cells arranged as ducts, acini and sheets of cells. Which of the following statements regarding this tumor is true?

choices.text: Most commonly affects male gender and smokers
Most common salivary gland tumor in adults.
Open biopsy is the gold standard investigation of choice
Facial nerve is commonly involved in this condition

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and image depicts a case of pleomorphic adenoma. The only true statement regarding pleomorphic adenoma is that it is the most common salivary gland tumor in adults.

Pleomorphic adenoma:

  • Most common benign salivary gland tumor.
  • The most commonly affected gland is the parotid gland. 
  • The superficial lobe is most commonly affected.
  • Also called the mixed tumor, since it has both epithelial and mesenchymal components.

Clinical features:

  • Most commonly affects females (Option -A) around 40 years of age.
  • Most common presenting feature – painless swelling below, in front and behind the ear.
  • The involvement of the deep lobe leads to dumbbell tumour – swelling in both the neck and oral cavity.

Specific features:

  • Slowly growing benign tumour
  • Unicentric in origin
  • Potentially malignant
  • Possibility of protrusion of fringes of the tumour mass through the capsule
  • Radioresistant
  • Usually affects adults, females > males
  • Painless swelling
  • Well-defined margins
  • Lobulated, firm, elastic-to-hard consistency
  • Free from deeper structures
  • No facial nerve involvement (Option-D)
  • The deep lobe pushes tonsils and faucial pillars

Diagnosis:

  • FNAC – investigation of choice. 
  • Open biopsy contraindicated due to chances of injury to the facial nerve and seedling of the tumour (Option-C)

Treatment: Surgery is the mainstay of treatment - Superficial parotidectomy (Patey's operation). Radiotherapy is considered in high-grade malignancies demonstrating extra-glandular disease, perineural invasion , direct invasion of surrounding tissue, or regional metastases.

Note: Malignant change occurs in about 1.5 to 9.5% of cases of pleomorphic adenoma and is referred to as carcinoma ex pleomorphic adenoma.

Symptoms suggestive of malignant transformation:

  • Rapid growth
  • Pain
  • Paraesthesias
  • Enlarged cervical lymph nodes
  • Restriction of jaw movements
  • Facial weakness
  • Skin invasion
  • Fixation of the mastoid tip.

Pathology:

Gross features:

  • The tumors are rounded, well-demarcated, measuring <6 cm in greatest dimension.
  • They are usually encapsulated, except in some areas such as the palate.
  • The cut surface is gray-white with myxoid and blue translucent areas of the chondroid (cartilage-like) stroma.

 

Microscopic features:

  • The epithelial elements resemble ductal cells or myoepithelial cells. They are arranged as ducts, acini, irregular tubules, strands, or sheets of cells.
  • These epithelial elements are dispersed within a background of loose myxoid and hyaline tissue containing islands of cartilage and, rarely, foci of bone.

The image below shows pleomorphic adenoma of the salivary gland consisting of mixed epithelial (left) and mesenchymal cell components (right).

Related Pearl: Important points regarding salivary gland tumors

  • Most common neoplasm of the salivary gland: Pleomorphic adenoma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • Most common benign tumor of the salivary gland in children: Hemangioma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland in children: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the minor salivary glands: Adenoid cystic carcinoma
  • Most common gland affected by pleomorphic adenomas: Parotid gland
  • Tumor of the salivary gland with perineural invasion: Adenoid cystic carcinoma
  • Tumor that shows a hot spot in 99mTc scan: Warthin’s tumor

questions.text: A 2-month-old baby is brought for a facial defect. On examination, the following findings were noticed. The soft and the hard palate are intact. Which of the following is the most appropriate management in this child?

choices.text: Cleft lip repair at 9 to 12 months
Cleft lip repair at 4 to 6 months

questions.solution:
The given clinical image is that of a child with a cleft lip on the left side and soft and the hard palate are intact. The most appropriate management for this patient would be a cleft lip repair at 4-6 months.

Etiology of the cleft lip can include familial, protein and vitamin deficiency, rubella infection, radiation, chromosomal abnormalities, maternal epilepsy and drug intake during pregnancy (steroids/eptoin/diazepam).

Majority of the cases are unilateral and cleft lip alone is uncommon.

The most appropriate management for this patient would be cleft lip repair at 4 to 6 months. 

According to Delaire timing of cleft surgery - unilateral cleft lip alone can be operated in one stage operation and is done at 4-6 months.

The different types of facial clefts are shown below:

  1. Unilateral cleft lip with alveolar involvement
  2. Bilateral cleft lip with alveolar involvement
  3. Unilateral cleft lip associated with cleft palate
  4. Bilateral cleft lip and palate
  5. Cleft palate only

Related Pearl: Timing of primary cleft lip and palate procedures:

Cleft lip alone

  • Unilateral (one side) - One operation at 5–6 months
  • Bilateral (both sides) - One operation at 4–5 months

Cleft palate alone

  • Soft palate - Only one operation at 6 months
  • Soft and hard palate - Two operations
    • Soft palate at 6 months
    • Hard palate at 15–18 months

Cleft lip and palate

  • Unilateral - Two operations
    • Cleft lip and soft palate at 5–6 months
    • Hard palate and gum pad with or without lip revision at 15–18 months
  • Bilateral - Two operations
    • Cleft lip and soft palate at 4–5 months
    • Hard palate and gum pad with or without lip revision at 15–18 months

Secondary management

  • Hearing, Prophylactic myringotomy, Regular audiological testing - 6–12 months

  • Speech, Velopharyngeal surgery, Speech and language therapy - 18 months

  • Orthodontic management

    - Mixed dentition - 8–10 years
    - Permanent dentition - 14-18 years

  • Excision of maxillary arch, Rhinoplasty - 16+ years

questions.text: A patient visits your clinic for follow-up after a breast surgery. She undergoes an x-ray scan, the findings of which are given below. Which of the following complications, if present in this patient, would show the linguine sign on MRI?
questions.solution:
The given x-ray shows silicone breast implants in a patient. MRI showing the linguine sign in post-silicone breast implant patients indicates intra-capsular silicone rupture.

After implantation of a silicone or saline breast implant, a fibrous capsule (scar) forms around the implant shell. In an intracapsular rupture, the contents of the implant are contained by the fibrous scar, while the shell appears as a group of wavy lines. This has been termed the linguine sign. It is seen in intra-capsular rupture of a breast implant.

Multiple hyperintense foci on T2-weighted images are sometimes found within the implant lumen. These findings are referred to as the “salad oil sign” or “droplet sign”.

Intracapsular rupture on MRI.

Breast implants are technically simple and it facilitates achieving symmetry. The implant in submuscular plane is better whenever a muscle is not removed during surgery. If the muscle is removed as in radical mastectomy, then a subcutaneous implant is placed. Silicone gel implants are used.

Complications may include pain, exposure of implant and rupture, infection, calcifications, displacements, intracapsular or extracapsular rupture and silicone granulomas.

MRI  of the breast can be used in the following cases:

  • To detect scar recurrence in women with a history of conservative breast surgery  
  • To assess the extent of high-grade ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS)
  • To assess multifocality and multicentricity in lobular cancer 
  • It is the best imaging modality for women with breasts implants
  • As a screening tool in high-risk women with a positive family history.

Generally, ultrasound(USG) is the preferred modality of imaging in suspected cases of extracapsular rupture. The Snowstorm sign on USG is seen in extracapsular rupture. (Option-B)

Other options:

Option B: In the case of extracapsular rupture of the silicone implant, it is detected by snowstorm appearance on USG.

Option C: Risk of anaplastic large cell lymphoma of scar tissue is increased in breast implant patients. This is confirmed by biopsy.

Option D: Calcifications in post-implant surgery patients can be detected on X-ray film. MRI used to detect contractures.

questions.text: A patient is admitted for evaluation of recurrent deep venous thrombosis. There is no history of any medical illness. All of the following investigations can be done for evaluating this patient except:
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of recurrent DVT in a patient warrants further investigation of the cause of deep venous thrombosis (DVT). DVT can occur in hypercoagulable states caused by either deficiency of protein C or antithrombin III. DVT can also occur in lupus anticoagulant/anticardiolipin syndrome characterized by antibodies to cardiolipin.

Antibodies to factor VIII causes deficiency of factor VIII leading to hemophilia (bleeding disorder).

Deep vein thrombosis:

Sites:

  1. Pelvic veins
  2. Leg veins—common in femoral and popliteal veins (common on the left side).

Features of DVT:

  • Fever- commonest
  • Tense, tender, warm, pale/bluish, shiny swelling calf
  • Positive Homan’s, Mose’s, or Neuhof’s signs
  • Inverted champagne bottle sign
  • Features of pulmonary embolism

Treatment:

  • Rest, the elevation of the limb, bandaging the entire limb with
  • crepe bandage.
  • Anticoagulants: Heparin/low molecular weight
  • heparin, warfarin, phenindione.
  • Palma operation
  • May-Husni operation

Choice of prophylaxis: 

  • Major trauma, abdominal and orthopedic surgeries warrants a longer duration of postoperative immobilization. The pharmacological method is efficacious in these situations.

  • Patients who are expected to be up and walking within 24 to 48 hours after minor trauma, operations are at low risk for the development of venous thrombosis. The mechanical method is advised in these situations. The simplest method is for the patient to walk. Activation of the calf pump mechanism is an effective means of prophylaxis.

Related Pearl: Risk factors for venous thromboembolism

Patient factors:

  • Age
  • Obesity
  • Varicose veins
  • Immobility
  • Pregnancy
  • Puerperium
  • High-dose estrogen therapy
  • Previous deep vein thrombosis or pulmonary embolism.

Thrombophilia

  • Congenital
    • Deficiency of antithrombin III, protein C or protein S
    • Antiphospholipid antibody or lupus anticoagulant
    • Factor V leiden gene defect or activated protein C resistance
    • Dysfibrinogenaemias
  • Acquired
    • Antiphospholipid antibody or lupus anticoagulant

Disease or surgical procedure

  • Trauma or surgery, especially of pelvis, hip, and lower limb
  • Malignancy, especially pelvic, and abdominal metastatic
  • Heart failure
  • Recent myocardial infarction
  • Paralysis of lower limb(s) infection
  • Inflammatory bowel disease
  • Nephrotic syndrome
  • Polycythaemia
  • Paraproteinaemia
  • Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria
  • Behçet’s disease
  • Homocysteinemia

questions.text:
Arrange the following colour codes used in triage in the increasing order of priority starting with the least priority.
  1. Red
  2. Black 
  3. Yellow
  4. Green
questions.solution:
Option C is the correct sequence of triage color coding.

2 Black
4 Green
3 Yellow
1 Red

 

Triage is used to classify the priority of treatment. Higher priority is given to victims whose prognosis would be good with simple medical care. Lower priority is given to moribund patients who would have questionable benefits even with medical attention.

Note:

In the event of a disaster, mass casualty or epidemic, hospitals face a significant demand or a surge for healthcare services that often outpaces the supply of available resources. Reverse triage is implemented during these surge periods.

By identifying and discharging low-risk patients, reverse triage allows faster and more efficient treatment of critically ill patients. It also helps minimize mortality and morbidity for the greatest number of patients while treating the largest number of patients in the shortest period of time.

Related Pearl: Triage Colour Coding

 Triage system consists of four colour codes:

Color code Type of patients Examples
Red (High priority)

Need for immediate resuscitation or surgery in the next 6 hours or transfer.

May survive if timely medical intervention can be given
  • Tension pneumothorax
  • Airway obstruction
  • Hemothorax
  • Cardiac tamponade
  • Acute circulatory arrest
  • Major intra-abdominal bleed etc.
Yellow (Medium priority)

Possible resuscitation or surgery in the next 24 hours.

Likely to survive if prompt treatment is given.
  • Compound fractures
  • Degloving injuries
  • Pelvic fracture
  • Spinal injuries
  • Moderate head injury
Green (Low priority)

Ambulatory patients or minor illnesses.

Likely to survive if treatment is slightly delayed.
  • Simple fractures
  • Minor lacerations etc.
Black (Least priority)

Dead or moribund patients.
  • Severe brain injury
  • Major damage / disruption to chest wall and abdominal structures

questions.text: A 29-year-old man who has come for his annual health checkup is found to have the following finding in the chest x-ray. His clinical examination is quite unremarkable and his abdomen is soft. You probe him regarding any significant symptoms and he responds that he has no complaints and has come only because the health check was free. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The radiograph shows pseudopneumoperitoneum which is seen in Chilaiditi’s syndrome. 

It is the harmless and asymptomatic interposition of the large bowel between the liver and diaphragm. It has to be differentiated from pneumoperitoneum because it does not require any intervention.

Features that suggest a Chilaiditi syndrome are:

  • The gas between the liver and diaphragm.
  • Rugal folds within the gas suggesting that it is within the bowel and not free.

Other options:

Pneumoperitoneum (option A) appears as subdiaphragmatic free gas.

Pneumopericardium (option B) appears as a dark line around the heart. (Indicated by the solid white arrow.)

questions.text: A 35-year-old man sustained a spinal cord injury as a result of a road traffic accident. On examination, his blood pressure is found to be 90/60 mmHg. All of the following findings can be seen in the patient except?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of the presence of hypotension associated with the spinal cord injury is suggestive of neurogenic shock. It is associated with bradycardia and not tachycardia.

Neurogenic shock refers to reduced tissue perfusion due to loss of vasomotor tone to peripheral arterial beds.

Neurogenic shock is usually secondary to spinal cord injuries due to vertebral body fractures of the cervical or high thoracic region that disrupts the sympathetic regulation of peripheral vascular tone. Loss of vasoconstrictor impulses results in increased vascular capacitance, decreased venous return and decreased cardiac output.

The classic description of neurogenic shock consists of:

  • Hypotension associated with bradycardia (absence of reflexive tachycardia due to disrupted sympathetic discharge)
  • Warm extremities (due to loss of peripheral vasoconstriction)
  • Motor and sensory deficits indicative of a spinal cord injury
  • Radiographic evidence of a vertebral column fracture

In addition, she has no venous complications like pigmentation, eczema, or venous ulcers. Thus, she can be initially managed with compression stockings. 

Compression stockings provide external pressure to the limb which compresses the veins and improves venous return. There are two lengths available - knee or thigh length. However, knee-length stockings are commonly prescribed as they have better compliance. 

They are useful for the initial management of varicose veins as they relieve symptoms and are a conservative approach. If the varicose veins become symptomatic or become visually distressing then non-conservative approaches described below can be considered. 

Other options: 

Option A: Radiofrequency ablation uses electromagnetic currents to destroy the vein without damaging the other structures. It can only treat junctional and truncal incompetence and not varicosities. 

Option B: Saphenopopliteal ligation is a surgical procedure where the saphenopopliteal junction is dissected with flush ligation. Alternatively, the small saphenous vein can also be ligated as proximally as possible. Sural nerve neuropraxia and common peroneal nerve injury are possible complications. 

Option C: Saphenofemoral ligation is a surgical procedure made where the great saphenous vein is ligated and stripped. There are complications associated with this procedure such as saphenous nerve injury and neovascularization due to trauma leading to reoccurrence.

questions.text:
A patient underwent a TAPP repair for an incarcerated left inguinal hernia. While fixing the mesh, tacks were accidentally placed below the iliopubic tract. On follow-up visits, the patient complained of persistent pain in his lateral thigh. Which of the following injury has most likely caused the pain?

TAPP - Transabdominal Preperitoneal
questions.solution:
Injury to the lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh is the most likely cause of pain in the above scenario.

It can be injured in laparoscopic hernia repair. 

In laparoscopic TAPP repair, to reduce chances of nerve injury during mesh placement, tacks are ideally placed above the iliopubic tract (away from the triangle of pain which carries the lateral femoral cutaneous nerve, the femoral branch of the genitofemoral nerve, and the femoral nerve).

Other options:

Option A: Ilioinguinal nerve may be commonly injured during open hernia repair. It provides innervation to the groin and medial aspect of the thigh, the upper part of the scrotum, and the penile root.

Option B: Iliohypogastric nerve can be injured while making an incision in the right iliac fossa during hernia surgery. It mainly supplies the suprapubic skin.

Option C: Femoral branch of the genitofemoral nerve (which supplies the skin over the upper anterior part of the thigh) lies in close relation to the lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh. Injury to these also can cause loss of sensation over the thigh but these are less frequent.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents to the clinic at 17 weeks of gestational age with a lump of 2 X 2 cm in the upper outer quadrant of her left breast, from 3 months. Which of the following investigations would you initially advise her for the assessment of the breast lump?
questions.solution:
Ultrasonography (USG) is the preferred initial investigation in pregnant women who present with a breast lump. It can differentiate between solid and cystic lesions of the breast and is able to detect abnormal axillary lymph nodes.

USG is preferred in pregnant women, lactating women, and young women (less than 40 years) since breast tissue is dense in these populations.

Other options:

Mammography (option A) is less useful in pregnant women due to the increased density of breast tissue.

MRI (option B) MRI is not the initial investigation used for the assessment of breast lumps. It can be used in cases where metastasis or spread to other breast is suspected.

Fine needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) (option D) is not recommended in pregnant women. It is difficult to distinguish breast cancer from the normal cellular proliferation in the breast tissue due to the hormonal changes.

questions.text: A patient complaining of pain in the right flank has been diagnosed with right-sided renal calculi measuring 2.2cm. Urine microscopy findings are shown in the image below. What is the most suitable treatment for this patient?

choices.text: No treatment required just pain management suffices

questions.solution:
The image of the urine microscopy shows hexagonal-shaped cystine stones. Hence the best suitable treatment for this patient with cysteine renal calculi measuring 2.2 cm is percutaneous nephrolithotomy (PCNL).

Cysteine stone is relatively resistant to extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy and a stone size of more than 2 cm necessitates percutaneous nephrolithotomy. Extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy is done until the renal stone size of less than 1.5cm.

PCNL is indicated in the following condition:

  • If the patient has anatomical obstruction like pelviureteric junction obstruction, calyceal diverticula, or distal ureteral obstruction.
  • Hard renal stones like cystine stones, and calcium oxalate stones.
  • If the renal stone is struvite stone as it is associated with urinary tract infection.

Extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy (ESWL) is a non-invasive method that generates shockwaves outside the body, which are focused on the stones. It is the commonest method of treating urinary tract stones nowadays. Stones up to approximately 1.5 cm in size are suitable for this form of treatment.

Complications of ESWL include infection, haematuria, parenchymal hemorrhage, and perirenal hematoma. ESWL is contraindicated in obese patients, pregnant patients, and patients taking oral anticoagulants.

Note: Stone fragments collected in the distal ureter following ESWL are called steinstrasse.

    • Dihydrate: Octahedral or envelope shaped
  • Struvite stones: Rectangular or coffin lid

questions.text:
A middle-aged woman presents with difficulty in swallowing both solids and liquids. A barium swallow revealed the following finding. What are all the investigations necessary for the following condition?

1. Timed barium study

2. Endoscopy

3. Esophageal manometry

4. 24-h pH monitoring
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with the barium swallow showing a bird beak appearance are suggestive of achalasia cardia. Timed barium study, endoscopy, and esophageal manometry are all necessary investigations for diagnosis of achalasia cardia.

Achalasia is a primary esophageal motility disorder. It is characterized by the absence of esophageal peristalsis and impaired lower esophageal sphincter (LES) relaxation in response to swallowing. These abnormalities cause a functional obstruction at the gastroesophageal junction. 

Esophageal manometry shows:

  • Incomplete LES relaxation in response to swallowing
  • High resting LES pressure
  • Absent esophageal peristalsis

On performing a timed barium study, barium will be retained for more than five minutes. The fluoroscopic examination will reveal a dilated esophagus that tapers to form a bird's beak at the gastroesophageal junction as seen in the image above. 

Endoscopy and biopsy are usually carried out to rule out cancer. 

24 hr pH monitoring is used in the diagnosis of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD).

Jejunal and ileal atresia: Multiple air-fluid levels (plain erect X-ray abdomen) presenting as triple bubble sign. 

 

Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis: Single enlarged gastric gas bubble - single bubble sign

 

Sigmoid volvulus: Coffee bean sign

questions.text: A worried mother brings her 18-month-old son to OPD with complaints of repeated urinary tract infections. During diagnostic work-up, pelvic USG shows the following finding. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with the USG showing the key-hole sign is suggestive of the posterior urethral valve (PUV). It is seen due to dilatation of the bladder and the proximal urethra.

The posterior urethral valves are membranes that have a small posterior slit, which lies just distal to the verumontanum. They function as flap valves and are obstructive to antegrade urinary flow.

The posterior urethral valve is the most common congenital cause of bladder outlet obstruction in males. PUV is classified into three types based on Young's classification.

Diagnosis is made antenatally with ultrasound, which demonstrates bilateral hydronephrosis above a distended bladder. If the diagnosis is not made antenatally, then neonates typically present with urinary infection or uremia and renal failure. 

The investigation of choice for a posterior urethral valve is micturating cystourethrography (MCUG).

Initially, the obstruction is relieved by catheterization to preserve renal function. Definitive treatment is by urethroscopic destruction of the valves with lifelong supportive treatment.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient, during his routine annual checkup, is found to have an abdominal aortic aneurysm measuring 40 mm in diameter on USG. Which of the following is true about the management of this patient?

choices.text: Surgery is indicated if aneurysmal diameter is >55mm
Urgently wheel the patient to OT for surgery
Surgery is indicated only if aneurysm is >77mm

questions.solution:
Surgery is indicated in asymptomatic abdominal aortic aneurysm only if its diameter is more than 55mm.

If the diameter is less than 55mm, regular ultrasound monitoring is required. This is because elective open surgery has a higher rate of mortality when compared to conservative management for aneurysms of size < 55mm.

Management of aortic aneurysm
AAA is surgically managed by dacron graft repair. It can be either open or EVAR.

  • Open surgical repair is done by exposing the aorta through a mid sternal incision and graft replacement. To expose the aorta the descending colon should be mobilized medially and this is known as left visceral rotation or Mattox procedure.
  • EVAR (endovascular aneurysm repair) is a minimally invasive procedure in which an aortic stent graft is placed on the nonaneurysmal aortoiliac segment.

Complications of following abdominal aortic aneurysm repair

  • Cardiovascular (ischemia and infarction)
  • Respiratory (atelectasis or consolidation).
  • Colonic ischemia.
  • Renal failure.
  • Aortoduodenal fistula
  • spinal cord ischemia

questions.text:
A patient following a road traffic accident presented with subcutaneous emphysema. On auscultation, there was no air entry on the right side. Vitals were unstable. What will be your immediate management?

e-FAST- Extended Focused Assessment with Sonography in Trauma

choices.text: Insertion of wide bore needle in the 5th intercostal space (ICS)
Wide bore needle decompression and IV fluids

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of no air entry on the right side with a history of road traffic accident and unstable vitals are suggestive of tension pneumothorax. The immediate management is the insertion of a wide-bore needle in the 5th ICS anterior to the mid-axillary line. This procedure is known as needle decompression or needle thoracostomy. 

Tension pneumothorax is a surgical emergency and the excessive pressure has to be immediately relieved. Tension pneumothorax is managed by immediate needle decompression in the 5th intercostal space (ICS), followed by definitive management with a chest tube inserted in the same space.

A tension pneumothorax develops when there is a tear is either in the parietal or visceral pleura. This tear acts as a one-way valve i.e. air enters from the lung or chest wall through it during inspiration but has no way to escape during expiration. This ultimately leads to the collapse of the affected lung.

It is characterized by chest pain, tachypnoea, tachycardia, hypotension, tracheal deviation away from the side of injury, absence of breath sounds on the affected side, and neck vein distention. A patient can develop subcutaneous emphysema as a complication, secondary to the pneumothorax. 

Other options:

Option B: While IV fluids are a part of the resuscitation protocol, hypotension in a tension pneumothorax is due to an obstructive type of shock, increasing circulating volume will have minimal effect on improving blood pressure. The management of the primary cause, tension pneumothorax, takes higher precedence as the next immediate step.

Option C: Intubation is performed when the patient is unresponsive post chest tube insertion. 

Option D: Extended Focused Assessment with Sonography in Trauma (eFAST) is not required before emergency decompression as tension pneumothorax is a clinical diagnosis, but it can be performed following chest tube insertion.

questions.text: A 24-year-old male is brought to the ER after he was hit by a motorbike as he was crossing the road. He sustained injuries over his abdomen with visible bruising. His blood pressure is 88/60 and IV fluids are immediately instituted. Which among the tests given below is indicated next in his patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette describes a case of blunt abdominal injury. In hemodynamically unstable patients ultrasound examination of the abdomen is indicated to decide the next step of management.

Blunt abdominal injury:

Primary assessment (ie, the primary survey) follows the ABCDE pattern: Airway, Breathing, Circulation, Disability (neurologic status), and Exposure. It is crucial to realize that the absence of abdominal pain or tenderness does NOT rule out the presence of significant intra-abdominal injury.

The following intraabdominal signs strongly correlate with intraabdominal injury

  • Seatbelt sign
  • Rebound tenderness
  • Hypotension 
  • Abdominal distension
  • Abdominal guarding
  • Concomitant femur fracture 

Following this management is as detailed in the protocol given below.

 

USG evaluation -

Bedside ultrasound (US) focuses on dependent intraperitoneal sites where blood is most likely to accumulate: the hepatorenal space (Morison's pouch), the splenorenal recess, and the inferior portion of the peritoneal cavity (including pouch of Douglas). These studies, when combined with an evaluation of the pericardium are referred to as the FAST exam (Focused Assessment with Sonography for Trauma).

questions.text: A patient who had undergone a thyroidectomy suddenly develops dyspnea with stridor. On examination, he had tachycardia and hypotension. Management of this case includes all of the following except:
questions.solution:
The above scenario is likely due to the development of a hematoma post-thyroidectomy. Hematoma formation post-thyroidectomy is managed by all the above methods except the administration of propylthiouracil. Propylthiouracil is used for the treatment of thyrotoxic crises.

Hematoma formation post-thyroidectomy occurs due to the slipping of ligatures of the superior thyroid artery, other pedicles, or small veins. This leads to venous edema of the larynx and can cause airway obstruction and respiratory distress.

Clinically, patients will have tachycardia, hypotension, breathlessness, stridor, and respiratory obstruction due to tension hematoma under strap muscles.

It is a life-threatening complication and should be monitored in the first 24 hours after surgery. As first aid, immediate release of sutures including deep fascia has to be done and pressure over the trachea is released. Then the patient is shifted to the operation theatre and under general anesthesia re-exploration is done and bleeders are ligated.

Laryngeal edema may occur due to a hematoma with tension, intubation injury, and surgical trauma. In this condition, along with evacuation of the hematoma, endotracheal intubation is also needed immediately to avoid airway obstruction. If it is impossible to intubate, a needle tracheostomy using a 12-gauge needle (2.3 mm diameter) is done temporarily.

Complications of thyroidectomy:

  • Hemorrhage - most common complication overall
  • Nerve injury 
    • External laryngeal nerve - hoarseness (more common)
    • Recurrent laryngeal nerve - hoarseness if unilateral, life-threatening aspiration and aphonia if bilateral
  • Respiratory obstruction
    • Laryngeal edema - the most common cause of respiratory obstruction
    • Bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy
    • Laryngomalacia
    • Tension hematoma
  • Hypoparathyroidism - infarction of parathyroids
  • Thyroid storm - inadequately prepared for surgery
  • Hypothyroidism
  • Recurrent thyrotoxicosis
  • Wound infection, stitch granuloma, keloid.

questions.text:
A chronic alcoholic patient presented with acute epigastric pain radiating to the back. The following sign is seen as shown in the image below. Lab investigations showed elevated serum amylase and lipase. What are the possible complications of the underlying condition?
  1. Coeliac artery thrombosis
  2. Pseudocyst formation
  3. Splenic vein thrombosis
  4. Sterile necrotic collection
  5. Infected necrotic collection
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image showing the grey turner's sign (discoloration of the flanks) are suggestive of acute pancreatitis. All the above-mentioned options could be possible complications except celiac artery thrombosis.

Acute pancreatitis can result in local and systemic complications. Local complications develop after the first week of the event and include:

Complication Description Management
Pancreatic pseudocyst
  • A well-encapsulated amylase-rich fluid collection outside the pancreas formed around 4 weeks after an attack of pancreatitis.
  • The fluid shows low CEA levels and cytology shows inflammatory cells.
  • Spontaneous resolution is common
  • Asymptomatic chronic thick-walled cysts may necessitate endoscopic, surgical, or percutaneous drainage due to the risk of complications. 
Acute peripancreatic fluid collection (APFC)
  •  A collection of sterile fluid in the peripancreatic tissues without encapsulation.

Usually resolves without any intervention but a large fluid collection may necessitate imaging-guided aspiration and drainage.
Sterile and infected pancreatic necrosis
  • Diffuse or localized peripancreatic fat breakdown results in a necrotic collection within and around the pancreas - acute necrotic collection(ANC).
  • The collection consists of fluid and necrotic material with an ill-defined wall that may be initially sterile but later become infected.
  • Over a period of time, the capsule is well formed and called a walled Off necrosis (WON).
 Management includes conservative measures and percutaneous drainage. In patients with overwhelming sepsis, laparotomy may be needed to perform a necrosectomy. Continuous post-operative closed lavage may be needed to prevent a recurrence.
Splenic vein thrombosis As a result of the procoagulant state during acute pancreatitis. Anti-platelet drugs. Endoscopic banding and beta blockers are used in the case of portal hypertension.

 
Pancreatic abscess A circumscribed intra-abdominal collection of pus around the pancreas. Imaging-guided percutaneous drainage under the cover of antibiotics
Pancreatic ascites

A generalized peritoneal effusion resulting from pancreatic duct disruption.

Amylase-rich fluid will be obtained through paracentesis.

 Imaging guided drainage with wide-bore drains
Hemorrhage Bleeding into the pseudocyst cavity or from a raw surface or pseudoaneurysm arising from a peripancreatic vessel. Embolization or surgery


The image given below shows pancreatic pseudocyst on a CT scan.

Systemic complications result from multi-organ damage and include acute respiratory distress syndrome, pleural effusions, gastrointestinal hemorrhage, renal failure, and disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC).

Related Pearl: Clinical features of acute pancreatitis

Symptoms:

  • Acute onset of epigastric pain, which is severe, constant, and refractory to usual doses of analgesics.
  • Typically radiates to back
  • Relieved in the sitting forward position
  • Nausea, repeated vomiting, retching, and hiccups

Signs:

  • Hypotension, tachycardia, and tachypnea
  • Grey Turner sign (A): bluish discoloration of the flanks
  • Cullen’s sign (B): bluish discoloration around the umbilicus
  • Fox sign: discoloration below the inguinal ligament
  • Pleural effusion (left > right): dullness on percussion, decreased breath sounds

Related Pearl: Laboratory findings in acute pancreatitis

  • Elevated serum amylase and serum lipase
    • Serum amylase level rises immediately and peaks in few hours and returns to normal in 3–5 days
    • Serum amylase level lacks specificity.
    • Serum amylase levels do not correlate with the severity of pancreatitis.
    • Serum lipase is more specific, and it is more useful when the patient presents 24–48 hours later.
  • Hyperglycemia
  • Hypocalcemia, hypoalbuminemia
  • Leukocytosis
  • Elevated serum levels of hepatic enzymes like alanine aminotransferase (ALT).
  • Azotemia, due to prerenal acute renal failure in case of severe fluid loss

Related Pearl: Vascular complications of pancreatitis

Arterial pseudoaneurysm:

  • It is caused by damage to the vessel wall by pancreatic elastase.
  • The most common vessel affected is the splenic artery, but the superior mesentric artery (SMA), cystic artery, and gastroduodenal artery (GDA) may also be affected.
  • Spontaneous rupture results in massive bleeding.
  • Clinical manifestations include sudden onset of abdominal pain, tachycardia, and hypotension.
  • Treatment
    • Arterial embolization
    • Ligation of the affected vessel in refrac­tory cases.

Vascular thrombosis:

  • Vessel usually affected is the splenic vein, but in severe cases, it can extend into the portal venous system.
  • Clinical features include splenomegaly, gastric varices, and splenic vein occlusion.
  • Treatment:
    • Mostly conservative.
    • Throm­bolytics in the acute early phase.

questions.text: A 3-year child is brought to the pediatrician for the evaluation of the neck mass. On examination, a painless, soft, fluctuating mass is found on the posterior triangle of the neck as shown in the image below. The slip sign is negative and the swelling is brilliantly transilluminant. Which of the following will not form the treatment option for this child?
questions.solution:
A soft, painless, brilliantly transilluminant, fluctuating mass found in the posterior part of the neck in a child, is most likely to be a cystic hygroma.

Cystic hygroma is a lymph-filled sac that results from the obstruction of the lymph vessels during their development. It is most commonly present in the posterior triangle of the neck. The mass may be apparent at birth or may appear in early childhood due to the increased accumulation of lymph. Since the sac is filled with lymph, it is soft, fluctuating, and brilliantly transilluminant.

Complications of cystic hygroma include respiratory difficulty, secondary infection, and chylothorax.

Management:

  • Primarily, the treatment includes aspiration (Option B) of the contents. Later once the sac or capsule gets thickened by fibrous tissue, it is excised.
  • Single cysts are treated with sclerosing therapy (Option C). Commonly used sclerosants include OK– 432 which is an inactive strain of group A Streptococcus pyogenes, pure ethanol, interferon α 2a, and doxycycline.
  • Multiple cysts are treated by complete excision of the cyst (Option D).

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presented with facial weakness and the following sign 4 days after undergoing total thyroidectomy. The probable cause of this condition includes all of the following except:

choices.text: Accidental ligature of inferior thyroid artery

questions.solution:
The given scenario and image showing carpopedal spasm are suggestive of hypocalcemia secondary to postoperative hypoparathyroidism. Thyroid insufficiency does not manifest with hypocalcemia.

Hypoparathyroidism is a rare complication of thyroidectomy which can occur as a transient event or due to the accidental removal of the parathyroid gland or ligation of the inferior thyroid artery. 

A rapid influx of serum calcium into bones in the immediate postoperative period may cause severe hypocalcaemia—hungry bone syndrome. It is more commonly observed in patients with beta-blockers. It is due to a sudden drop in PTH level after surgery.

Mostly it is temporary due to vascular spasm of parathyroid glands, which occurs on the 2nd-5th postoperative day.

Symptoms and signs of hypocalcemia:

  • Mild circumoral or digital numbness
  • Paresthesia
  • Laryngeal spasms 
  • Cardiac arrhythmias 
  • Chvostek sign: This is elicited by gently tapping over the facial nerve in front of the tragus of the ear. There is hyperexcitability of the facial muscles, manifesting as a contraction of the muscles.

The hand goes into a painful carpopedal spasm and assumes the accoucheur’s hand position. (as shown in the image)
  • Muscle weakness is the earliest feature of hypocalcemia.

Serum calcium estimation is done and then 10 ml of 10% calcium gluconate is given intravenously 8th hourly. Later supplemented by oral calcium carbonate 500 mg 8th hourly. After 3–6 weeks, the patient is admitted, the drug is stopped and the serum calcium level is repeated.

questions.text:
Which of the following is correct regarding the current American cancer society (ACS) colorectal cancer screening recommendations for the average-risk population?
  1. Screening should begin at the age of 55 years
  2. An annual fecal occult blood test (FOBT)
  3. Flexible sigmoidoscopy every 5 years
  4. Double-contrast barium enema (DCBE) every 2 years
  5. Colonoscopy every 10 years
questions.solution:
An annual faecal occult blood test (FOBT), flexible sigmoidoscopy every 5 years, or colonoscopy every 10 years are the recommended tests according to the current American Cancer Society (ACS) colorectal screening guidelines for the average-risk population.

Current ACS guidelines advocate screening the average-risk population for colorectal carcinoma beginning at age 50 years. Screening recommendations include the following:

  1. Annual faecal occult blood test (FOBT), or
  2. Flexible sigmoidoscopy every 5 years, or
  3. FOBT and flexible sigmoidoscopy in combination every 5 years, or
  4. Air-contrast barium enema every 5 years, or
  5. Colonoscopy every 10 years.

A positive FOBT should be followed by a colonoscopy.

Patients with other risk factors (considered a high-risk population) should be screened earlier and more frequently, as shown below:

Population Initial age Recommendation
Familial colorectal cancer first-degree relative 40 years of age or 10 years before the age of the youngest affected relative (whichever is earlier) Colonoscopy every 5 years
Inflammatory bowel disease (Crohn's disease or ulcerative colitis) At diagnosis; then 8 years after diagnosis Colonoscopy with multiple biopsies every 1–2 years
Familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) 10–12 years of age Annual flexible sigmoidoscopy
Lynch syndrome (HNPCC) 20–25 years of age Colonoscopy every 1–2 years

questions.text: Identify the procedure shown in the image given below:
questions.solution:
The procedure shown in the image is Whipple's procedure. 

The following structures are removed during Whipple’s procedure:

  • Distal stomach
  • Duodenum
  • Proximal jejunum
  • Head of the pancreas
  • Gallbladder
  • Common bile duct (CBD)
  • Regional lymphatics

The Whipple procedure is a complex surgery done for carcinomas involving the head of the pancreas. It is done only in cases when:

  • The entire duodenum has to be removed e.g. in familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP)
  • Tumour encroaches in the first part of the duodenum, or stomach
  • A clear resection margin is not achieved by pylorus-preserving pancreatoduodenectomy

Other options: 

Option B: In Billroth II loop gastrojejunostomy, two-thirds of the stomach is removed, the duodenal stump is closed and the stomach is anastomosed to the jejunum. It helps to re-establish gastrointestinal continuity following antrectomy for complicated peptic ulcer disease.

Option C: Kasai procedure or Roux-en-Y hepato-porto-enterostomy is done for all types of extrahepatic biliary atresia. It involves the excision of all extrahepatic bile duct remnants up to the liver capsule and the gallbladder. Following this, a Roux-en-Y loop of jejunum is mobilized and anastomosed to the exposed area of the liver capsule above the bifurcation of the portal vein creating a portoenterostomy.

The Kasai procedure or Roux-en-Y hepato-porto-enterostomy is shown in the image below.

Option D: Roux-en-Y gastric bypass is used as bariatric surgery where a small proximal gastric pouch is created at the lesser curvature of the stomach and a roux limb of 75 - 150 cm (jejunum) is created by anastomosing the proximal jejunum to the gastric pouch and, a shorter biliary/biliopancreatic limb of 30 - 50 cm (consisting duodenum and proximal jejunum) is anastomosed to the roux limb via side to side jejunojejunostomy.

questions.text: A patient is undergoing laparoscopic cholecystectomy for acute cholecystitis. The surgeon accidentally injures the bile duct. Intraoperative cholangiography shows a complete transection of the common bile duct without loss of ductal length. What is the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
The intraoperative cholangiography shows a complete transection of the common bile duct without loss of a segment. This is managed with T-tube placement.

Laparoscopic cholecystectomy is the most common cause of bile duct injury. Biliary injury during laparoscopic cholecystectomy results from failure to define the surgical anatomy owing to visual perceptual error. 

Clinically, patients with post-cholecystectomy bile duct injury present with right upper quadrant pain, fever, nausea, and jaundice (in case of strictures).

Investigations show leukocytosis and elevated liver enzymes (ALP and GGT). The use of cholangiography helps in delineating the management of bile duct injuries during cholecystectomy.

When a bile duct injury is detected during surgery, the laparoscopic cholecystectomy is changed to an open procedure. If a major injury is discovered and an experienced surgeon is unavailable, an external drain is placed, and the patient is transferred to a referral center.

questions.text: A 38-year-old male patient presented to surgery OPD with a history of intermittent purulent discharge with a slight blood tinge from an external opening located in the perianal region. The location of the external opening was at 8’O clock position. Which of the following statements is false regarding the management of this disease?

choices.text: MRI is the gold standard modality of investigation
Seton's technique induces fibrosis and  has very good evidence of healing
Sphincter division can lead on to sphincter dysfunction and incontinence
Laying open fistulotomy shows improvement but does not eradicate the disease

questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette is suggestive of fistula-in-ano. Laying open fistulotomy is the surest management method to eradicate the disease. 

Fistula-in -ano:

A fistula-in-ano is an abnormal hollow tract or cavity that is lined with granulation tissue and that connects a primary opening inside the anal canal to a secondary opening in the perianal skin.

The most common cause is perianal abscess. Other causes include tuberculosis or Crohn's disease.

Symptoms:

  • Perianal pain
  • Discharge - intermittent purulent discharge (which may be bloody) 

Goodsall's rule:

Goodsall’s rule can be used as a guide in determining the location of the internal opening of the fistula.

  • Fistulas with an external opening anteriorly connect to the internal opening by a short, radial tract.
  • Fistulas with an external opening posteriorly track in a curvilinear fashion to the posterior midline.

Exceptions to Goodsall’s Rule

However, exceptions to this rule often occur: Fistulas with an anterior external opening greater than 3 cm from the anal margin usually track to the posterior midline.

Investigations:

The investigations available for fistula-in-ano are as follows:

  • Fistulogram
  • Endoanal ultrasound
  • MRI
  • Computed tomography (CT) scan
  • Endocoil MRI
  • Hydrogen peroxide–enhanced 3-D endoanal ultrasonography

Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is the gold standard investigation for fistula imaging. It helps us to identify the secondary extensions of the track, which when missed may cause persistence of the fistula. (Option-A)

Treatment:

  • Control of constipation
  • Sitz bath
  • Fistulotomy
  • Fistulectomy
  • Ligation of intersphincteric fistula tract (LIFT)
  • Setons
  • Advancement flaps

Important points to remember:

Laying open is the surest method of eradication, but sphincter division may result in incontinence due to sphincter dysfunction(Option-C)

Seton's technique:

Seton’s technique is used in the management of fistula-in-ano. The seton should be non-absorbable, non-degenerative, and comfortable. A seton is a drain placed through a fistula to maintain drainage and/or induce fibrosis. It is left in place for 3 months. Seton's technique induces fibrosis and has very good evidence of healing. If there is evidence of good healing it is removed. (Option-B)

For fistulas that involve more than 30% of the sphincter or those which are distal to the dentate line, loosely placement of seton through the track helps to facilitate drainage of any sepsis and to preserve the sphincter.

This may be converted to a cutting seton by gradually tightening at regular intervals to promote fibrosis and to slowly cut through the involved sphincter muscle, thus helps in eliminating the fistula while maintaining the continuity of the sphincter.

questions.text: A young patient who suffered a large wound due to a road traffic accident was referred to you after initial wound management. As a plastic surgeon, you decide to cover the wound with the following type of graft. Which of the following is not a feature of the graft used by the plastic surgeon?

choices.text: It is also known as Thiersch graft
Only dressing is enough at donor site
This graft has the best cosmetic appearance

questions.solution:
The given image shows the procedure of obtaining a split-thickness skin graft using a handheld Humby knife. The best cosmetic appearance is generally seen with full-thickness skin grafts. 

The most preferable donor site is buttock in cosmetically sensitive individuals and children. The most commonly used donor site is the thigh.

  • The graft is taken from the donor site with a handheld Humby knife or dermatome knife.
  • Grafts are perforated to allow exudates to escape and improve ‘take’. It can further be meshed to allow expansion.
  • Grafts will take up only on the beds which are vascularized, hence preparation of wound bed is an essential step.
  • Skin grafts are completely dependent on nutrition on the tissue over which they are placed and can heal well over muscle, perichondrium, and periosteum. They do not take well over bone or cartilage or on tissue that has been irradiated or infected or is hypovascular.
  • A clean healthy wound bed with a meshed graft tied in place to stop movement will encourage take.
  • The presence of group A beta-hemolytic streptococci is a contraindication in grafting as it can destroy split grafts completely and also convert donors to full-thickness defects.
  • The donor area is dressed appropriately and the dressing is opened after 10 days and not earlier. 

The given image shows Humby's knife. The average thickness of the graft obtained from a Humbys knife is 0.3 mm.

 

Split thickness skin graft (Thiersch graft ): Partial-thickness skin grafts consisting of the epidermis and a portion of the dermis are called split-thickness skin grafts.

Full-thickness skin grafts (Wolfe graft) include the epidermis and entire dermis, with portions of the sweat glands, sebaceous glands, and hair follicles. 

Advantages of split skin graft over full-thickness skin graft:

  • Large grafts can be harvested.
  • In the case of thinner split-thickness grafts, the donor site heals more rapidly and can be reused in severe cases such as burns.
  • Uptake is good. Meshing can be done i.e. small splits are made in graft and any exudates collected can come out through this and this improves graft take up. 
  • Meshing also allows the graft to expand.

Advantages of full-thickness skin graft over split skin graft:

  • It has a lesser degree of post graft contraction
  • Best cosmetic appearance as they include the highest number of skin appendage elements.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient involved in a road traffic accident was brought unconscious to the emergency room. CT brain reveals the following findings. All of the following are indications for performing an open craniotomy in this patient except?

choices.text: A GCS drop of 4 points in a comatose patient
A GCS drop of 6 points  in a comatose patient

questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario and the plain computed tomography (CT) scan shows a concavo-convex-shaped hematoma on the left side suggestive of an acute subdural hematoma (SDH). A midline shift > 5mm is considered an indication for performing an open craniotomy.

Acute SDH results from the accumulation of blood between the arachnoid membrane and the dura. The tearing of a bridging vein running from the cerebral cortex to the dural sinuses is the most common cause of acute SDH.

On head CT scan, acute SDH appears as a hyperdense, crescent-shaped (concavo-convex) lesion (as seen in this question)

Open craniotomy for the evacuation of acute SDH is indicated for the following:

  1. Thickness >1 cm
  2. Midline shift >5 mm

Emergent decompression is also recommended to a comatose patient with an acute subdural hematoma less than 1 cm in thickness causing a midline shift of less than 5 mm if any of the following criteria are met:

  •  GCS drops by two or more points from the time of injury to the hospitalization
  •  The patient presents with fixed and dilated pupils
  • ICP is >20mm Hg

Match the following features with their corresponding syndromes

 

Features Syndrome
A. Pheochromocytomas, medullary carcinoma of the thyroid, parathyroid hyperplasia 1. MEN 1
B. Parathyroid adenoma, pituitary adenoma, adrenal tumor, testicular tumor 2. MEN 2A

C. Mucosal neuromas, Marfanoid habitus, pheochromocytoma, medullary carcinoma of the thyroid

 3. MEN 2B
D. Hyperparathyroidism, gastrinomas, prolactinomas  4. MEN 4
questions.solution:
The correct matched option is A-2, B-4, C-3, and D-1.

Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia (MEN) refers to a group of inherited syndromes including various benign and malignant tumors of endocrine glands. There are four types - MEN 1-4. They have an autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance and can also be sporadic. 

MEN 1 is a syndrome complex associated mainly with parathyroid adenoma, pancreatic tumors, and pituitary tumors. 

MEN 2A comprises mainly medullary thyroid carcinoma, pheochromocytoma, and parathyroid adenoma. 

MEN 2B/3 consists of medullary thyroid carcinoma, pheochromocytoma, mucosal neuroma, marfanoid habitus, medullated corneal nerve fibres, and megacolon.

MEN 4 is associated with parathyroid adenoma, pituitary adenoma, and reproductive organ tumors.

  • Pituitary adenoma – Most common is prolactinoma

Associated tumors are:

  • Angiofibroma
  • Collagenomas
  • Adrenal cortical tumors
  • Lipoma
  • Neuroendocrine tumors - gastric, thymic, lungs
  • Meningioma
  • Pheochromocytoma
  • Carcinoid tumors, usually of the foregut

    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (90%)

questions.text: A patient was brought following blunt abdominal trauma. On examination, he was hemodynamically stable. Contrast-enhanced CT (CECT) showed splenic trauma with a subcapsular hematoma over 30% of the surface area. Angiography and embolization were done but failed to achieve hemostasis. Which of the following is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
The next step in management is splenorrhaphy. 

The non-expanding subcapsular hematoma over 30% of the surface area is suggestive of grade II splenic injury. These patients are managed by angiography and embolization, and if it fails, the next step in management is a spleen-saving technique or splenorrhaphy.

Splenorrhaphy is a procedure done to preserve the spleen parenchyma. These involve all the surgical procedures done to save the spleen parenchyma while splenectomy is the entire surgical removal of the viscera. Splenorrhaphy should not be performed if the patient is unstable if there are multiple injuries or extensive splenic injury. 

Grades of splenic injury:

Grade Injury
I Non-expanding subcapsular hematoma (<10% of surface area) or laceration, <1 cm of parenchymal depth
II Non-expanding subcapsular hematoma (10-50% of surface area) or laceration, 1-3 cm of parenchymal depth which does not involve the trabecular vessels
III

Hematoma > 50% of surface area or expanding

  • Ruptured subcapsular or parenchymal hematoma,
  • Intraparenchymal hematoma >5 cm or expanding Or
    Laceration, >3 cm parenchymal depth or involving
    trabecular vessels
IV Laceration involving segmental or hilar vessels leading to major devascularization (>25% of the spleen)
V Shattered spleen
or
A hilar vascular injury that devascularizes the spleen.

Management of splenic trauma:

Grade I and II injuries:

They are usually hemodynamically stable and are managed non-operatively. Initially, these patients are managed conservatively with regular monitoring of vitals, hematocrit, and serial CECT.

If the grade of injury is found to increase, then angiography and embolization of the bleeding vessel are done to achieve hemostasis. If angiography and embolization fail to achieve hemostasis, or if the patient becomes hemodynamically unstable, then a splenorrhaphy is done.

Grade III injuries that are hemodynamically stable are managed like that of grades I and II, while those that are hemodynamically unstable are managed like that of grades IV and V.

Grade IV and V injuries patients are usually hemodynamically unstable and splenectomy is done.

Other options: 

Option A: Repeat angiography and embolization are unlikely to help as it has already failed once in this patient. 

Option B: Conservative management will not stop the ongoing hemorrhage that is present in this patient. It is useful in patients who are no longer bleeding. 

Option C: Splenectomy is not required in this patient as they have a grade II injury and are still hemodynamically stable.

Related Pearl: American Association for the Surgery of Trauma (AAST) Spleen Injury Scale

Related Pearl: Indications for Selective Non-Operative Management (SNOM) in splenic trauma

Indications :

  • Patient younger than 55 years
  • Grade I, II, or III (in selective cases) splenic injury
  • Physiologic stability, as indicated by normal blood pressure, lack of tachycardia, absence of physical examination findings indicating shock, and absence of metabolic acidosis.

questions.text: A postoperative patient comes for a follow-up visit to have his sutures removed. Which of the following blades will you use?
questions.solution:
A number-12 blade is used for suture removal.

A 12-size blade is a small, pointed, crescent-shaped blade used typically as a suture cutter. It is most sharp on the inside edge of its curve.

The number on a surgical blade communicates both its size and its shape. The different surgical blades are shown below:

Other options:

Option A: The 11-size blade has an oblique edge with a sharp-pointed tip and hence it is known as a "stab knife". 

Uses:

  • Commonly used to incise skin, subcutaneous tissue, and deep fascia to open the abscess cavity in a single stroke, during incision and drainage (I & D) of an abscess.
  • This blade can also be used for inserting drains and arteriotomy.

Option C: The 15-size blade has a narrow shaft and is often used for minor surgical procedures. 

Uses of 15-scalpel blade:

  • To make precise skin incisions in dermatosurgery
  • Minor surgical procedures
  • Select ocular procedures (15C blade)
  • Select plastic surgery procedures (15C blade)

Option D: The 10-size blade is used for skin incisions.

Note: The 22-size blade is often used for abdominal incisions. Essentially a larger version of the number 10, it has a flat, unsharpened back edge and a short, curved cutting edge. These blades are best for creating large incisions, often through thick skin. Surgical blades no. 20, 21, 22, 23, and 24 have a wide shaft and are used for larger incisions.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient with a history of chronic smoking presented with Intermittent calf pain. Angiography shows an inverted tree-like appearance of arteries of both lower limbs. All of the following clinical features can be seen in this patient except:
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis of the given scenario is thromboangiitis obliterans / Buerger disease. Acrocyanosis is persistent, painless cyanosis seen in fingers and often in legs with paraesthesia and chilblains affecting young females. It has no association with TAO.

Buerger's disease is a progressive nonatherosclerotic segmental inflammatory disease that most often affects small- and medium-sized arteries, veins, and nerves of the lower extremities. It is characterized by occlusive disease of small- and medium-sized arteries, thrombophlebitis of the superficial or deep veins, and Raynaud’s syndrome.

Clinical features:

  • Common in male smokers below 40 years of age group
  • Intermittent claudication in foot and calf progressing to rest pain, ulceration, gangrene.
  • Recurrent migratory superficial thrombophlebitis.
  • Absent/feeble pulses distal to proximal; dorsalis pedis, posterior tibial, popliteal, femoral arteries.
  • May present as Raynaud’s phenomenon.
  • Raynaud's phenomenon is episodic vasospasm. It leads to a sequence of clinical features called Raynaud’s syndrome comprising of local syncope, local asphyxia, and local recovery.

Investigations:

Arterial doppler and duplex scan (doppler + B-mode U/S).

Transfemoral retrograde angiogram through Seldinger technique shows blockage—sites, extent, and severity

  • The corkscrew appearance of the vessel is due to dilatation of vasa vasorum.
  • Inverted tree/spider leg collaterals.
  • Severe vasospasm causing corrugated/rippled artery. 
  • Distal runoff is the amount of dye filling in the main vessel distal to the obstruction through collaterals. If the distal run-off is good then ischemia is compensated. If the distal run-off is poor then ischemia is decompensated.

Treatment:

Cessation of smoking is the definitive management. 

Drugs to improve circulation include

  • Pentoxifylline
  • Aspirin
  • Clopidogrel
  • Statins 
  • Cilostazol- Phosphodiesterase inhibitor is ideally used to improve circulation in the collaterals formed.
  • Vasodilators and anticoagulants have no role in the treatment.
  • Care of limb with Buerger’s exercise and positioning 
  • Surgical management may include lumbar sympathectomy and amputation according to the presenting features.

questions.text: A 24-year-old lady presented with vomiting, abdominal distention, and postprandial epigastric pain.  A barium meal follow-through of the patient is given below. Which of the given statements regarding the patient's likely condition is false?

choices.text: Third part of the duodenum is compressed
Angle between superior mesenteric artery and aorta is more obtuse (>100)
This condition is also called as Wilkie’s syndrome

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the barium follow-through demonstrating dilation of the duodenum with an abrupt cut-off at its third part, coinciding with the line of the superior mesenteric artery is suggestive of superior mesenteric artery (SMA) syndrome/Wilkie syndrome. In this condition, the angle between the superior mesenteric artery and the aorta is more acute (<20 degrees).

Wilkie syndrome is usually seen in young women who are physically weak. It is a rare condition in which the SMA compresses the third portion of the duodenum. The normal aortomesenteric angle is between 38-65 degrees. This is reduced to 20 degrees (according to some texts it is 15.2 degrees and in some, it is 18 degrees) in SMA syndrome. The SMA obstructs the third part of the duodenum by compressing it against fixed retroperitoneal structures. 

Symptoms include epigastric pain which is episodic and postprandial in nature, nausea, vomiting, abdominal distention, and weight loss.

SMA syndrome is associated with:

  • Rapid childhood growth
  • Profound weight loss
  • Abdominal surgery
  • Inflammatory diseases of the abdomen
  • Immobilization in a cast that increases lordosis and accentuates the angle of the SMA with the aorta (cast syndrome)

Upper gastrointestinal barium studies are used for diagnosis. CT is also useful in some cases.

Treatment includes:

  • Medical therapy- frequent small feedings, lying on prone or left side postprandially, weight gain, or removal of a body cast improves symptoms.
  • Laparoscopic lysis of the ligament of Treitz is beneficial in a few cases.
  • The following surgical procedures can be done- duodenojejunostomy, gastrojejunostomy, and duodenal derotation (Strong procedure).

questions.text: A patient was found to have an adrenal mass during a routine health checkup. What is the most common cause of adrenal mass in this condition?
questions.solution:
The most common cause of clinically unapparent adrenal lesion that is incidentally detected in imaging studies is incidentaloma. The majority of these lesions are non-functional i.e benign.

Incidentalomas are evaluated to classify them as:

  • Non-functional (75%): most common 
  • Functional: may present with Cushing's syndrome, phaeochromocytoma, Conn's syndrome, etc.
  • Secondary metastasis (2%): from breast, lung, and kidneys are seen in 2% of the patients 

Management of incidentalomas:

  • Non-functional: Tumors with a size <4cm are managed conservatively. MRI surveillance is done every 3-6 months. For size >4cm, laparoscopic adrenalectomy is done.

  • Functional tumours: Hormonal assay studies are done in suspected functional tumours or patients presenting with symptoms. If positive, it should be managed accordingly. If not managed, functional tumours can become malignant and the incidence increases 4-fold if the size of the lesion crosses 4 cm.

  • Secondary metastasis: Fine-needle aspiration and biopsy is performed. Tests for pheochromocytoma should always be done before this procedure to avoid precipitating a hypertensive crisis.
